title: Gumband
summary: Service-based CMS for experiential teams, focused on reliability over flash.
oneLiner: A service-based CMS for experiential teams—built to be dependable, not flashy.
problem: Agencies needed a CMS that didn’t fight their process. Most tools were web-first, fragile around devices/scheduling, or too bespoke to maintain. We set out to build a platform that handled real install constraints without slowing teams down.
scope: Full-stack engineering on the core platform
Defined service boundaries and simplified the data model
Improved developer experience (docs in code, clearer local/dev flows)
Standardized patterns for content → device sync and scheduling
Partnered on product decisions and backlog prioritization
decisions: Chose platform boundaries that matched on-site workflows
Cut two nice-to-haves to stabilize content flows and QA earlier
Wrote small utilities over framework-specific magic for maintainability
Introduced predictable patterns for sync, status, and error handling
Prototyped an integration plugin to unblock a partner team
outcome: A reliable CMS foundation teams could actually use. Clearer expectations about what the platform supported and faster onboarding for new work. (Project paused after org changes.)
notes: If I did it again, I’d pilot on one site and productize the patterns from there, and ship an integration SDK from day one.

teaser.subline: Built the unglamorous parts so teams could move without worry.
